  - id: 12_the_defense_industry_in_poland_an_offsets_based_revival_pdf__cmo_016
    text: By requiring buyback and local sourcing, offsets redirect procurement-related spending toward domestic suppliers
      (including subsidiaries) and expand a local industrial footprint.
    rationale: Buyback and local sourcing compensate for imports by redirecting spending to domestic suppliers.
- theme_id: PM74
  theme_label: Disclosure constraints obscure evaluation
  mechanism_explanation: Limited data access and vested interests constrain disclosure, making it difficult to separate fact
    from fiction in offset evaluation.
  mechanisms:
  - id: 10_evaluating_defense_offsets_the_experience_in_finland_and_sweden_pdf__cmo_002
    text: Limited data access and vested interests in industry and government constrain disclosure and complicate separating
      fact from fiction.
    rationale: Data access limits and vested interests obscure evaluation.
- theme_id: PM75
  theme_label: Counterfactual uncertainty undermines additionality
  mechanism_explanation: When counterfactual outcomes are unknown, analysts must assume them, creating fundamental uncertainty
    about additionality.
  mechanisms:
  - id: 10_evaluating_defense_offsets_the_experience_in_finland_and_sweden_pdf__cmo_003
    text: Because it is unknown what would have happened without the offset obligation, analysts must assume a counterfactual,
      introducing fundamental uncertainty about additionality.
    rationale: Unknown counterfactuals create fundamental uncertainty about additionality.
- theme_id: PM77
  theme_label: Heterogeneity limits generalization
  mechanism_explanation: Differences in offset types and goals produce divergent effects and require different evaluation
    approaches, limiting generalization.
  mechanisms:
  - id: 10_evaluating_defense_offsets_the_experience_in_finland_and_sweden_pdf__cmo_005
    text: Heterogeneity in offset types and goals produces different economic effects and requires different evaluation methods,
      limiting generalization.
    rationale: Diverse offset types require different evaluation methods and limit generalization.
  - id: 10_evaluating_defense_offsets_the_experience_in_finland_and_sweden_pdf__cmo_012
    text: Indirect offsets (reciprocal purchases unrelated to the arms deal) obscure causal attribution and complicate evaluation
      compared to direct offsets.
    rationale: Indirect offsets complicate causal attribution relative to direct offsets.
- theme_id: PM78
  theme_label: Exports concentrate in incumbents
  mechanism_explanation: Offset-generated exports concentrate in existing trade relations and traditional products from large
    exporters, limiting SME exports and job creation.
  mechanisms:
  - id: 10_evaluating_defense_offsets_the_experience_in_finland_and_sweden_pdf__cmo_007
    text: Offset-generated exports concentrate in existing trade relations and traditional products from large exporters,
      limiting SME exports and job creation.
    rationale: Exports concentrate in incumbents, limiting SME gains.
- theme_id: PM80
  theme_label: Firm gains but weak national benefit
  mechanism_explanation: Offset receipt can correlate with firm income/employment gains even when national net benefits are
    limited and misaligned with policy goals.
  mechanisms:
  - id: 10_evaluating_defense_offsets_the_experience_in_finland_and_sweden_pdf__cmo_010
    text: Statistical association between receiving offsets and firm income/employment growth can coexist with limited national
      net benefit and poor alignment with policy goals.
    rationale: Firm-level gains can coexist with weak national net benefit.
- theme_id: PM81
  theme_label: Offsets extend activity beyond program life
  mechanism_explanation: Emphasis on indirect offsets is used to extend industrial activity beyond the life of a specific
    procurement program, sustaining work over time.
  mechanisms:
  - id: 10_evaluating_defense_offsets_the_experience_in_finland_and_sweden_pdf__cmo_015
    text: Emphasis on indirect offsets was initially used to extend industrial activity beyond the life of a specific procurement
      program.
    rationale: Indirect offsets are used to extend industrial activity beyond a single program.

title: Offsets
text:
Prompt: Initial Discovery of Proto-Mechanism Themes
ROLE You are supporting a realist evidence synthesis. Your task is to identify and group mechanism statements into proto-mechanism themes.
You are working inductively. There are no pre-existing themes.
Your core analytic question is:
“Are these different surface descriptions of the same underlying generative process?”
A generative process explains how or why an outcome is produced (e.g., learning, dependency, trust formation, signalling, institutional friction).
INPUT
You will receive a list of mechanism statements, each with an ID.
Mechanisms describe causal processes, not just events or outcomes.
ANALYTIC RULES 1) Focus on causal processes
Group statements that describe the same type of underlying mechanism, even if wording, actors, sectors, or outcomes differ.

Ignore outcomes for now

Do not cluster based on similar outcomes (e.g., delays, interoperability, cost growth). Focus only on how the outcome is generated.

Do NOT group by:

shared country or programme
shared sector
general topic similarity (e.g., “technology”, “industry”)
shared outcomes only

Each cluster must represent ONE mechanism

If two statements involve “technology transfer” but describe different processes (e.g., learning vs. restriction), they belong in different themes.

Use AMBIGUOUS when necessary

If a mechanism could plausibly reflect more than one underlying process and cannot be confidently grouped, mark it as AMBIGUOUS.
TASKS
Step 1 — Interpret mechanisms
For each statement, identify the underlying generative process it appears to describe.
Step 2 — Form proto-mechanism themes
Group mechanisms that reflect the same generative logic.
Step 3 — Name each theme
Provide a short label (3–6 words) describing the mechanism.
Good examples:
“Trust building through co-production”
“Capability dependency on foreign suppliers”
“Learning-by-doing in domestic industry”
“Political signalling via industrial cooperation”
“Administrative burden from compliance”
Bad examples:
“Technology issues”
“Industrial effects”
Step 4 — Explain each mechanism theme
Write 1–2 sentences describing the shared causal process in realist terms (how it works and why it produces effects).
Step 5 — Justify assignments
For each mechanism in a theme, explain briefly:
“This belongs here because it describes the process where…”
Step 6 — Flag ambiguous mechanisms
List any mechanisms that could fit multiple themes and explain why classification is uncertain.
CONSTRAINTS - Keep every original mechanism ID and statement text intact. - Do not invent or split mechanism statements. - Use concise rationales (1 sentence each). - Do not add commentary outside the required YAML. - Do not omit any mechanism.
YAML CHECKLIST - Output valid YAML only (no preamble or epilogue). - Use spaces for indentation (no tabs). - Keep consistent indentation (2 spaces per level). - Quote strings containing punctuation. - Ensure every list item starts with “-”.
OUTPUT FORMAT (STRICT YAML) proto_mechanism_themes: - theme_id: PM1 theme_label: “Trust building through co-production” mechanism_explanation: “Repeated joint production fosters interpersonal and organisational trust, shaping expectations and willingness for future collaboration.” mechanisms: - id: MECH_001 text: “Full mechanism statement” rationale: “Describes trust emerging from sustained joint work.” - id: MECH_007 text: “Full mechanism statement” rationale: “Reflects the same trust-building process despite different wording.”

theme_id: PM2 theme_label: “Capability dependency on foreign suppliers” mechanism_explanation: “Domestic capability gaps lead actors to rely on foreign firms, creating structural dependence that shapes long-term industrial and strategic choices.” mechanisms:

id: MECH_003 text: “Full mechanism statement” rationale: “Describes reliance caused by capability shortfall.”


ambiguous_mechanisms: - id: MECH_011 text: “Full mechanism statement” possible_themes: [PM2, PM4] explanation: “Could reflect dependency or political signalling depending on actor intent.”

title: Offsets
text:
You are extracting realist-style Context–Mechanism–Outcome (CMO) configurations from ONE document at a time.
DEFINITIONS (MUST APPLY) - Context (C): The salient conditions that shape whether/how the mechanism fires (e.g., institutional rules, alliance relationships, procurement regime, industrial base maturity, governance capacity, threat environment). Context should be a condition or setting, not a program action; it can include pre-existing structures, constraints, incentives, or capacities. - Mechanism (M): The underlying generative causal process that produces change, typically framed as: (programme resources/constraints) + (actors’ reasoning/response) -> causal force Mechanisms are NOT the same as activities, outputs, or policies (avoid “setting up an office”, “signing an MoU” as mechanisms). The mechanism should explain why actors respond the way they do given the resources/constraints. - Outcome (O): The observed (or credibly reported) effect(s), intended or unintended (e.g., interoperability, security of supply, cost/schedule impacts, corruption risk, industrial capability, alliance integration). Outcomes are effects or changes, not activities or plans.
TASK 1) Read document_text carefully. 2) Identify and extract ALL defensible CMO configurations evidenced in the document. - Prefer “small” CMOs anchored to a specific claim/passage. - Do not stop at the first CMO; include additional distinct CMOs if the text supports them. - If the document only implies a CMO, you may still extract it but set confidence to low and make the inference explicit in the paraphrase. 3) Write each C, M, and O concisely (ideally 1–3 sentences each). 4) Populate metadata fields: - programme: name of the programme linked to the offset deal (snake_case). If not stated, use unknown_programme (do NOT guess). - country: snake_case country name; use multi_country if needed; if not stated, use unknown_country. - research_questions_mapped: list of RQ IDs from the list below (e.g., [rq1, rq3]) - evidence_type: one of case_study | comparative_case_study | theory_model | legal_analysis | policy_report | survey_experiment | systematic_review | qualitative_interviews | mixed_methods | other - evidence_type_narrative: 1–2 sentences describing what kind of material this is and why you chose evidence_type. - supporting_evidence: a SHORT direct quote (max ~25 words) that supports the CMO. Use double quotes inside YAML; escape internal quotes. If no suitable short quote exists, use “” and rely on paraphrase. - supporting_evidence_paraphrase: 1–2 sentences paraphrasing the supporting passage and how it supports the CMO (may note if inference is being made). - confidence: low | medium | high based on how directly the text supports the CMO. - confidence_justification: 1–2 sentences explaining the confidence rating (e.g., direct explicit CMO vs partial/implicit, specificity of evidence).
VALIDATION AND VERIFICATION (V&V) REQUIREMENTS - Validate each CMO against the source text: - supporting_evidence must directly support the CMO; if not, lower confidence and say so in the paraphrase. - If the CMO is inferred, explicitly state that in the paraphrase and set confidence to low. - Ensure context is a condition/setting (not an activity or policy). - Ensure mechanism is a causal process linking resources/constraints to actors’ reasoning/response (not just an activity or policy). - Ensure outcome is an effect or change (observed or credibly reported) and do not overclaim beyond the text. - Ensure programme and country values are snake_case. - Produce a V&V log summarizing checks, issues, and any adjustments.
OUTPUT RULES (MUST FOLLOW) - Output ONLY valid YAML (no markdown, no commentary). - The YAML top level MUST be a mapping keyed by the FILE NAME exactly as given in file_name. - Under the file key, include ONLY: - cmos: a mapping from unique CMO IDs to CMO objects - v_and_v_log: a list of V&V entries (may be empty) - If you find no defensible CMO, output: : cmos: {} v_and_v_log: - check: no_defensible_cmo status: pass note: “No defensible CMO found in this document.” - Each CMO ID MUST be derived from the file name: a) Create file_slug by: - lowercasing - replacing all non-alphanumeric characters with underscores - collapsing multiple underscores to one - trimming leading/trailing underscores b) Append __cmo_### where ### is a zero-padded 3-digit index starting at 001. - Each CMO object MUST have exactly these keys (and in this order): context mechanism outcome programme country evidence_type evidence_type_narrative research_questions_mapped supporting_evidence supporting_evidence_paraphrase confidence confidence_justification - Programme/country values MUST be snake_case. - Lists MUST be valid YAML lists (use hyphens). - Avoid long quotations; do not invent facts not supported by the text.
V&V LOG FORMAT - Each v_and_v_log entry MUST have exactly these keys: check status note - status must be one of: pass | warn | fail - Include at least these checks per file: - completeness_all_relevant_cmos - evidence_traceability - context_is_condition - mechanism_is_causal - outcome_is_effect - snake_case_fields - quote_length - inference_flagged
RESEARCH QUESTIONS (choose any that fit; can assign multiple per CMO) - rq1: Alliance relevance and mechanisms — Through what mechanisms do offset or industrial participation policies affect alliance-relevant outcomes such as interoperability, standardisation, security of supply, readiness, and the ability to contribute rapidly to NATO operations? - rq2: Conditions for durable collaboration — Under what conditions do offsets lead to durable industrial collaboration with allies and close partners (co-development, co-production, licensed production, shared sustainment/MRO, trusted supply chains)? - rq3: Risks and mitigation — What partnership risks are most commonly associated with offsets (corruption vulnerability, export-control friction, programme fragmentation, market distortion, cost/schedule impacts), and what mitigations/governance designs reduce these risks? - rq4: Positive comparative cases — Which countries combine continuing offset/industrial participation policy with high allied programme integration, and what design features enable coexistence? - rq5: Negative or mixed comparative cases — Which countries exhibit offset-related frictions that undermine partnership/alliance integration outcomes, and what policy design features appear implicated?
NOW DO THE EXTRACTION FOR THE PROVIDED INPUTS AND OUTPUT ONLY YAML.

title: Offsets
text:
Prompt: Proto-Mechanism Theme Merge Audit (One Theme at a Time)
ROLE You are supporting a realist evidence synthesis. Your task is to audit whether ONE target proto-mechanism theme is redundant and should be merged into a better-fitting existing theme.
You must classify by underlying generative causal process, not topic similarity.
INPUTS YOU WILL RECEIVE

target_theme_id The theme ID to audit (e.g., PM17).
proto_themes_yml The full current contents of: data/mechanism_themes/proto_themes.yml
proto_themes_changelog_yml The full current contents of: data/mechanism_themes/proto_themes_changelog.yml

REFERENCE EXTRACTION (PYTHON) — USE THIS WORKFLOW EVERY TIME
Use this code structure to ensure you consistently compare the target theme to ALL other themes’ labels and explanations. (This is a workflow reference; do not execute it.)
import re
import yaml

proto = yaml.safe_load(proto_themes_yml)  # dict
themes = proto["proto_mechanism_themes"]  # list[dict]

theme_index = {
  t["theme_id"]: {
    "theme_label": t["theme_label"],
    "mechanism_explanation": t["mechanism_explanation"],
  }
  for t in themes
}

target_theme = next(t for t in themes if t["theme_id"] == target_theme_id)
other_themes = [t for t in themes if t["theme_id"] != target_theme_id]

changelog = yaml.safe_load(proto_themes_changelog_yml)
existing_ids = [
  int(re.search(r"CHG_(\\d+)$", c["change_id"]).group(1))
  for c in changelog.get("change_log", [])
  if re.search(r"CHG_(\\d+)$", c.get("change_id", ""))
]
next_change_num = (max(existing_ids) + 1) if existing_ids else 1
AUDIT TASK (FOR THE TARGET THEME ONLY)

Compare the TARGET theme’s:


theme_label
mechanism_explanation

against EVERY OTHER theme’s: - theme_label - mechanism_explanation

Decide ONE outcome:


NO MERGE (KEEP TARGET AS DISTINCT) Choose this if no other theme clearly captures the same generative process as the target.
MERGE TARGET INTO AN EXISTING THEME Choose this if another theme’s label/explanation describes the same causal process more clearly or more canonically than the target theme.

MERGE DECISION RULES (STRICT)

Use generative process similarity, not:

shared outcomes
shared country/programme
shared sector / platform
surface keywords

“Same process” means: if you replaced the target theme label/explanation with the candidate’s label/explanation, you would not lose any distinctive causal logic.
Only recommend a merge when the overlap is strong and specific. If overlap is partial or the target theme appears to bundle multiple distinct processes, do NOT merge in this task (record no_change).

EDITING RULES (STRICT)

If you recommend NO MERGE:

Do not change proto_themes.yml theme content.

If you recommend MERGE:

Do not change any mechanism id or text.
Move ALL mechanisms from the target theme into the destination theme’s mechanisms list (append).
Ensure each mechanism appears exactly once across all themes (no duplicates).
Remove the target theme from proto_mechanism_themes after moving its mechanisms.
Do not “clean up” unrelated themes.


CHANGE LOGGING (UPDATE EXISTING YAML CHANGE LOG)
Append a new entry to data/mechanism_themes/proto_themes_changelog.yml for this run:

If merged: change_type: merge
If not merged: change_type: no_change

Each entry must include: - change_id: next sequential ID (CHG_###), continuing from the current max - theme_id: the destination theme ID (if merged) OR the audited target_theme_id (if no merge) - summary: 1 sentence describing what changed (include from/to theme IDs when merged) - rationale: 1–2 sentences justifying the decision in terms of causal process similarity/difference - details: - merged_from: list of merged theme IDs (empty if no merge) - merged_into: destination theme ID (null if no merge) - reviewed_theme_id: the audited target theme ID
OUTPUT FORMAT (TWO STRICT YAML DOCUMENTS)
Return TWO YAML documents separated by a line containing only ---.
Document 1 will be saved to: data/mechanism_themes/proto_themes.yml Document 2 will be saved to: data/mechanism_themes/proto_themes_changelog.yml
Document 1 MUST match this schema:
proto_mechanism_themes: - theme_id: PM1 theme_label: “Label” mechanism_explanation: “Explanation” mechanisms: - id: MECH_001 text: “Full mechanism statement” rationale: “Why it fits this theme’s causal process.”
ambiguous_mechanisms: - id: MECH_031 text: “Full mechanism statement” possible_themes: [PM2, PM4] explanation: “Why assignment is ambiguous; what evidence would resolve it.”
Document 2 MUST match this schema:
change_log: - change_id: CHG_123 change_type: merge | no_change theme_id: PM7 summary: “Merged PM12 into PM54.” rationale: “PM12 and PM54 describe the same technology-acquisition causal process; PM54 is the clearer canonical label/explanation.” details: merged_from: [PM12] merged_into: PM54 reviewed_theme_id: PM12
Do not include any commentary outside the TWO YAML documents.

title: RQ1 Synthesis
text:
Alliance relevance and mechanisms — Through what mechanisms do offset or industrial participation policies affect alliance-relevant outcomes such as interoperability, standardisation, security of supply, readiness, and the ability to contribute rapidly to NATO operations?
This synthesis uses only the RQ1-coded CMO statements. The evidence base mixes high-confidence case studies/comparative case studies with a small number of more conceptual/theory-model claims; where outcomes are framed as “expected” or “aimed”, these are treated as conceptual rather than empirically observed. (calcara_20_pdf__cmo_002, weiss_19_pdf__cmo_003, kanniainen_17_pdf__cmo_002)



Interoperability and Standardisation (n≈9)
Readiness and Sustainment Support (n≈20–25)
Security of Supply and Autonomy (n≈10–15)
Defence-Industrial Capability and Technology Transfer (n≈20–30)
Programme Performance, Cost, and Governance (n≈10–15)
Alliance Political Leverage, Trust, and Network Position (n≈5–10)





Programmatic integration for common standards: In contexts where multilateral operations and interoperability priorities drive cooperation, pooling and standardising equipment is framed as a route to interoperability. Mechanism: cooperation provides economies of scale and standardisation, aligning equipment and practices across partners. Outcome: improved interoperability/standardisation (often stated as expected rather than directly measured). (weiss_19_pdf__cmo_002, calcara_20_pdf__cmo_002)
Offsets embedded in alliance-linked defence sales: In contexts of established security relationships and export-driven defence sales, offsets/industrial compensation are used as inducements. Mechanism: offering technology transfer/production arrangements within sales packages reinforces alliance ties and supports interoperability aims. Outcome: defence sales proceed with industrial compensation explicitly embedding alliance-building and interoperability goals. (16_offset_policies_and_trends_in_japan_south_korea_and_taiwan_pdf__cmo_001)
Interoperability-driven technology sharing under constraint: In contexts where interoperability requirements are tied to sensitive technologies, interoperability can require technology release. Mechanism: achieving interoperability necessitates sharing sensitive technology with partners (sometimes conditional on technology-access arrangements and approvals). Outcome: sensitive technology is shared with partners; governance around technology release becomes an active constraint on the pathway. (hagelin_12_pdf__cmo_002, 08_offsets_and_the_joint_strike_fighter_in_the_uk_and_the_netherlands_pdf__cmo_006)
Interoperability as a driver of costly acceleration dynamics: In contexts combining interoperability priorities with budget constraints and political pressure, technology sharing is framed as creating pressure to advance next-generation development. Mechanism: interoperability/technology sharing is used to justify accelerating “next generation” development to preserve an edge. Outcome: higher taxpayer costs and an arms-race dynamic among allies. (05_arms_trade_as_illiberal_trade_pdf__cmo_017)





Direct offsets building maintenance/modification competence: In contexts where imported systems generate sustainment dependence, direct military offsets can be targeted at maintenance and modification capacity. Mechanism: offsets provide resources/training/work packages that build local maintenance and modification capability, shifting actors toward in-country sustainment. Outcome: strengthened domestic sustainment competence supporting readiness. (10_evaluating_defense_offsets_the_experience_in_finland_and_sweden_pdf__cmo_017, 16_offset_policies_and_trends_in_japan_south_korea_and_taiwan_pdf__cmo_021)
Targeted MRO skill formation through selective cooperation: In contexts of small-state constraints and explicit prioritisation of sustainment skills, offsets/IP are used selectively for training and specialised repair/upgrade activities. Mechanism: collaboration and training requirements focus learning-by-doing on readiness-critical subsystems rather than broad industrialisation. Outcome: expanded MRO/upgrade capacity and improved overhaul capability for lifecycle support. (17_offsets_and_defense_industrialization_in_indonesia_and_singapore_pdf__cmo_013, 17_offsets_and_defense_industrialization_in_indonesia_and_singapore_pdf__cmo_014, 17_offsets_and_defense_industrialization_in_indonesia_and_singapore_pdf__cmo_015)
Re-focusing offsets towards defence-relevant sustainment outcomes: In contexts where policy shifts away from civil/economic offsets toward defence-technology competence (and/or where military requirements must dominate procurement), offset demands are redirected. Mechanism: restricting offsets’ role in supplier selection and prioritising defence-relevant technology/sustainment objectives reduces distortion and concentrates offset effort on lifecycle-support competencies. Outcome: offsets are redirected to defence-industrial participation and maintenance/technology competence and constrained to a secondary role in procurement evaluation. (10_evaluating_defense_offsets_the_experience_in_finland_and_sweden_pdf__cmo_016, 09_nordic_offset_policies_changes_and_challenges_pdf__cmo_004, 09_nordic_offset_policies_changes_and_challenges_pdf__cmo_008)
Boundary conditions from scale and duration of support: In contexts of very small fleets and limited support commitments, sustainment economics become fragile. Mechanism: small scale and short windows for spares/support weaken long-term supportability and deter external buyers. Outcome: high sustainment costs and reduced export viability (with sustainment activity potentially persisting only in narrow forms). (14_the_argentine_defense_industry_an_evaluation_pdf__cmo_010, 14_the_argentine_defense_industry_an_evaluation_pdf__cmo_007, 14_the_argentine_defense_industry_an_evaluation_pdf__cmo_005)





Security of supply via maintenance capacity (including theory-model claims): In contexts where importers face security risks and dependence, offsets are framed as improving security by sustaining maintenance capability and equipment availability. Mechanism: offsets function as an “insurance” logic and/or build maintenance capacity that reduces vulnerability to external suppliers. Outcome: improved security of supply / strengthened national security (noting this includes theory-model framing). (kanniainen_17_pdf__cmo_002, kanniainen_17_pdf__cmo_003, 10_evaluating_defense_offsets_the_experience_in_finland_and_sweden_pdf__cmo_017)
Autonomy through software/mission-system control (and export-control friction): In contexts where autonomy goals hinge on software maintenance and technology evolution, buyers design offsets around technology transfer to enable in-country control. Mechanism: creating domestic entities for software development/technology absorption and requiring transfer of sensitive artefacts increases control over operation, maintenance, and upgrades; suppliers’ willingness/ability to release technology becomes a binding constraint. Outcome: strengthened operational/maintenance autonomy, with bidder disadvantage where source-code transfer is non-negotiable. (13_offsets_and_the_development_of_the_brazilian_arms_industry_pdf__cmo_017, 13_offsets_and_the_development_of_the_brazilian_arms_industry_pdf__cmo_019, 13_offsets_and_the_development_of_the_brazilian_arms_industry_pdf__cmo_020)
Interoperability path dependence reducing supplier diversity: In contexts where operational interoperability with US-made systems increases in importance, procurement choices can narrow toward US systems and US-led models. Mechanism: interoperability requirements constrain feasible sourcing and reinforce a path-dependent procurement trajectory. Outcome: reduced supplier diversity and greater reliance on JSF-style buy-multinational procurement models. (18_defense_offsets_in_australia_and_new_zealand_pdf__cmo_021)
Constrained autonomy and diluted defence linkage through indirect offsets: In contexts where offsets/DIP are used to keep an in-country defence industry viable but obligations are met via indirect offsets/investment, defence linkage can dilute. Mechanism: broadening compliance space beyond defence work sustains firms and regional activity but can undercut ambitions for an independent defence industrial base and leave key capabilities underdeveloped. Outcome: constrained autonomy, diluted defence linkage, and missed capability development (e.g., shipbuilding proper). (20_defense_offsets_and_regional_development_in_south_africa_pdf__cmo_009, 19_defense_industrial_participation_the_south_african_experience_pdf__cmo_008, 20_defense_offsets_and_regional_development_in_south_africa_pdf__cmo_020)
Supplier discovery as a potential security-of-supply pathway (tentative): In contexts of uncertain supplier efficiency, offsets are described as enabling discovery of efficient suppliers and long-term partnerships. Mechanism: offset-linked engagement reveals new suppliers and builds relationships. Outcome: improved supply-chain integration, with security-of-supply benefits described as possible rather than demonstrated. (ianakiev_14_pdf__cmo_004)





Learning-by-doing via licensed production and staged localisation: In contexts of sustained procurement-linked production arrangements, capability accumulation is framed as incremental. Mechanism: technology transfer, training, assembly/parts manufacture, and continued production create learning curves and absorptive capacity over time. Outcome: improved industrial capability/technology absorption and increased local content/production capability. (15_the_role_of_offsets_in_indian_defense_procurement_policy_pdf__cmo_004, 12_the_defense_industry_in_poland_an_offsets_based_revival_pdf__cmo_017, 13_offsets_and_the_development_of_the_brazilian_arms_industry_pdf__cmo_001)
Absorptive capacity as a moderator of technology-transfer effectiveness: In contexts with stronger R&D institutions and educated personnel, technology transfer is more readily internalised and extended. Mechanism: human-capital and institutional capacity increases absorptive capacity, shaping how much transferred technology becomes domestically usable. Outcome: more effective “technology ladder” ascent under structured institutional capacity. (13_offsets_and_the_development_of_the_brazilian_arms_industry_pdf__cmo_003, 15_the_role_of_offsets_in_indian_defense_procurement_policy_pdf__cmo_004)
Supply-chain insertion and capability-preserving participation: In contexts where industrial participation is constrained by value-for-money procurement, IP is structured to avoid displacing capability/price priorities. Mechanism: requiring defence-related, technically equivalent work within contract constraints incentivises supply-chain insertion (including via SMEs) while keeping IP secondary in award decisions. Outcome: procurement priority preserved with benefits flowing to SMEs through supply-chain insertion. (07_comparing_british_and_german_offset_strategies_pdf__cmo_003)
Sustaining high-technology niches in small states: In contexts of small-state constraints and high-technology sector priorities, offsets/IP provide access to specialised production and know-how. Mechanism: offset-linked work and (partly) foreign-financed investments channel resources into domestic firms that sustain and upgrade capabilities otherwise hard to finance. Outcome: sustained aerospace/engine manufacturing capabilities and improved technical know-how. (11_offsets_in_belgium_between_scylla_and_charybdis_pdf__cmo_004, 11_offsets_in_belgium_between_scylla_and_charybdis_pdf__cmo_001)
Domestic prime leadership in co-development enabling higher-end capability: In contexts where the buyer maintains financial/budgetary leadership and a domestic prime role in program structure, technology transfers are embedded within a domestic-led production/integration effort. Mechanism: domestic prime authority + embedded transfers build manufacturing and integration capability while preserving export flexibility. Outcome: higher-end aerospace capability and export positioning. (16_offset_policies_and_trends_in_japan_south_korea_and_taiwan_pdf__cmo_014)
Capability erosion under offset-dependent participation: In contexts where industrial participation is mainly offset-dependent work (rather than substantive collaboration or independent programmes), design and systems-integration learning can be reduced. Mechanism: reliance on offset-dependent tasks reduces opportunities to build/retain high-end design and integration experience. Outcome: erosion of long-run national design/systems-integration capability. (08_offsets_and_the_joint_strike_fighter_in_the_uk_and_the_netherlands_pdf__cmo_005)





Complex governance and non-competitive work splitting increasing cost/delay: In contexts of collaborative procurement with juste-retour style work allocation and multi-layer governance, programmes become administratively heavy. Mechanism: non-competitive splitting and committee structures increase transaction costs, blur accountability, and slow decisions. Outcome: inefficiency, higher costs, and programme delays. (08_offsets_and_the_joint_strike_fighter_in_the_uk_and_the_netherlands_pdf__cmo_001)
Relaxing strict work-share rules as an efficiency pathway (contingent): In contexts where collaborative procurement tensions exist around juste-retour vs alternative work-share approaches, shifting work-share rules is treated as a lever. Mechanism: moving from strict national shares toward “global balance” reduces fragmentation and can improve collaborative efficiency, but depends on political agreement and acceptance of perceived disadvantages. Outcome: improved efficiency / reduced fragmentation (conditional). (07_comparing_british_and_german_offset_strategies_pdf__cmo_009)
Constraining offsets to reduce procurement distortion: In contexts where procurement must be driven by military requirements and value-for-money, offsets are explicitly constrained. Mechanism: prohibiting offsets from influencing supplier choice until requirements are met reduces distortion in capability selection. Outcome: offsets take a secondary role in procurement evaluation. (09_nordic_offset_policies_changes_and_challenges_pdf__cmo_008, 07_comparing_british_and_german_offset_strategies_pdf__cmo_003)
Steering supplier behaviour with eligibility criteria and multipliers (governance instrument): In contexts where offset programmes specify what “counts” and provide multipliers, suppliers are nudged toward higher-valued activities. Mechanism: eligibility rules and multipliers reshape incentives, increasing proposals for R&D/training and other preferred activities relative to low-value or relabelled work. Outcome: contractors focus on technology-intensive activities (as credited compliance behaviour). (18_defense_offsets_in_australia_and_new_zealand_pdf__cmo_003)
Shift away from ill-focused offsets toward more specific provisions: In contexts where offsets are judged ill-focused, states replace broad offset approaches with narrower mechanisms. Mechanism: targeting sustainment-relevant capabilities and then substituting contract-specific provisions/local-content requirements aims to concentrate on self-reliance-relevant outcomes while reducing offset-related inefficiencies. Outcome: offsets abolished de facto and replaced by more specific contractual provisions. (18_defense_offsets_in_australia_and_new_zealand_pdf__cmo_005)





Offsets/IP as political assurance within alliance relationships: In contexts of tenuous security environments and high dependence on an external guarantor, offsets and arms sales can be valued for assurance effects. Mechanism: offset-inclusive purchases reinforce political/alliance-building signals, shaping decision-makers’ willingness to continue offset-inclusive procurement. Outcome: continued pursuit of offsets for political assurance alongside industrial benefits. (16_offset_policies_and_trends_in_japan_south_korea_and_taiwan_pdf__cmo_018, 16_offset_policies_and_trends_in_japan_south_korea_and_taiwan_pdf__cmo_001)
Offsets creating network ties that shape power and leverage: In contexts where arms-production networks matter for political leverage, offsets are treated as tools to create interdependence. Mechanism: offset clauses create network ties; direct offsets can help technologically advanced states maintain central positions, while indirect offsets can lock less-capable states into peripheral roles. Outcome: shifts in network position/power and offsets pursued primarily for political leverage (with outcomes moderated by initial capability). (spindel_24_pdf__cmo_001, spindel_24_pdf__cmo_002, spindel_24_pdf__cmo_003, spindel_24_pdf__cmo_004)
Interdependence and trust pathways (limited evidence): In contexts of coordinated procurement and cooperation, interdependence and socialisation are proposed as pathways to more cooperation/trust. Mechanism: coordinated responses create interdependence that drives greater cooperation; cooperation may strengthen trust via socialisation (framed with lower-confidence “other” evidence). Outcome: greater defence cooperation and strengthened trust. (kollias_25_pdf__cmo_002, weiss_19_pdf__cmo_003)




Across domains, the RQ1 CMOs imply that alliance-relevant effects hinge less on the existence of offsets/IP per se than on how they are structured and governed: (09_nordic_offset_policies_changes_and_challenges_pdf__cmo_008, 18_defense_offsets_in_australia_and_new_zealand_pdf__cmo_003, 08_offsets_and_the_joint_strike_fighter_in_the_uk_and_the_netherlands_pdf__cmo_001)

Absorptive capacity and programme structure condition technology transfer: where institutional/human-capital capacity exists, transferred know-how is more plausibly internalised; where programmes embed staged localisation and learning-by-doing, technology absorption is framed as improving over time. (13_offsets_and_the_development_of_the_brazilian_arms_industry_pdf__cmo_003, 12_the_defense_industry_in_poland_an_offsets_based_revival_pdf__cmo_017, 15_the_role_of_offsets_in_indian_defense_procurement_policy_pdf__cmo_004)
Sustainment-focused designs more directly connect to readiness and security of supply: direct offsets and targeted cooperation aimed at maintenance/modification/MRO are repeatedly linked to readiness-relevant capabilities, whereas broad industrialisation goals are treated as diverging strategies. (10_evaluating_defense_offsets_the_experience_in_finland_and_sweden_pdf__cmo_017, 17_offsets_and_defense_industrialization_in_indonesia_and_singapore_pdf__cmo_002, 17_offsets_and_defense_industrialization_in_indonesia_and_singapore_pdf__cmo_013)
Governance choices can mitigate or amplify distortion: rules that keep offsets secondary to military requirements/value-for-money are explicitly framed as anti-distortion safeguards; conversely, complex collaborative governance and non-competitive work splitting are linked to higher costs/delays. (09_nordic_offset_policies_changes_and_challenges_pdf__cmo_008, 07_comparing_british_and_german_offset_strategies_pdf__cmo_003, 08_offsets_and_the_joint_strike_fighter_in_the_uk_and_the_netherlands_pdf__cmo_001)
Export-control/technology-release constraints are binding moderators: where autonomy or interoperability requires sensitive technology release (e.g., software source code), outcomes depend on supplier willingness/ability and approval processes, which can reshape competition and feasible partnering. (13_offsets_and_the_development_of_the_brazilian_arms_industry_pdf__cmo_020, hagelin_12_pdf__cmo_002, 08_offsets_and_the_joint_strike_fighter_in_the_uk_and_the_netherlands_pdf__cmo_006)
Scale and market viability constrain sustainment and export outcomes: small fleets and short support commitments are linked to high sustainment costs and weak export prospects, limiting any alliance-relevant benefits from domestic participation. (14_the_argentine_defense_industry_an_evaluation_pdf__cmo_010, 14_the_argentine_defense_industry_an_evaluation_pdf__cmo_007)

The CMOs also point to mixed/contested implications: interoperability can be supported by programme integration and standardisation, but is also framed as generating costly acceleration dynamics under budget and political pressures. (16_offset_policies_and_trends_in_japan_south_korea_and_taiwan_pdf__cmo_004, 05_arms_trade_as_illiberal_trade_pdf__cmo_017)




In contexts where imported systems create sustainment dependence, offsets/IP may support readiness and faster operational contribution by building in-country maintenance/modification competence via direct military offsets or sustainment-centred cooperation. (10_evaluating_defense_offsets_the_experience_in_finland_and_sweden_pdf__cmo_017, 17_offsets_and_defense_industrialization_in_indonesia_and_singapore_pdf__cmo_014)
In contexts where interoperability is prioritised, alliance outcomes may be supported through multinational programme structures (joint development/risk sharing) that integrate partners into common standards earlier, potentially reducing reliance on post-sale offsets. (16_offset_policies_and_trends_in_japan_south_korea_and_taiwan_pdf__cmo_004, weiss_19_pdf__cmo_002)
In contexts where domestic absorptive capacity is strong (R&D institutions, trained personnel), offsets/IP may support security-of-supply-relevant autonomy by enabling technology absorption and domestic control over sustainment and evolution (including software). (13_offsets_and_the_development_of_the_brazilian_arms_industry_pdf__cmo_003, 13_offsets_and_the_development_of_the_brazilian_arms_industry_pdf__cmo_017)
In contexts where technology release is constrained (export controls, source-code restrictions), offsets/IP may fail to deliver autonomy/interoperability pathways; procurement may need to treat technology-access feasibility as a binding condition rather than an assumed benefit. (13_offsets_and_the_development_of_the_brazilian_arms_industry_pdf__cmo_020, hagelin_12_pdf__cmo_002)
In contexts where collaborative programmes rely on non-competitive work splitting and complex governance, alliance capability goals may be undermined by cost/delay and fragmentation; constraining offsets’ role in supplier selection is one stated guardrail. (08_offsets_and_the_joint_strike_fighter_in_the_uk_and_the_netherlands_pdf__cmo_001, 09_nordic_offset_policies_changes_and_challenges_pdf__cmo_008)
In contexts where political assurance or leverage is a primary objective, offsets/IP may function as alliance-management tools by creating interdependence and network ties; strategy should treat this as a distinct mechanism from capability/readiness outcomes. (16_offset_policies_and_trends_in_japan_south_korea_and_taiwan_pdf__cmo_018, spindel_24_pdf__cmo_004)
Boundary condition / risk of overreach: where domestic production is small-scale/non-competitive or offsets are met via indirect/investment channels that dilute defence linkage, intended readiness/autonomy gains may not materialise and opportunity costs may be high. (14_the_argentine_defense_industry_an_evaluation_pdf__cmo_002, 19_defense_industrial_participation_the_south_african_experience_pdf__cmo_008, 20_defense_offsets_and_regional_development_in_south_africa_pdf__cmo_020)

title: RQ1 Synthesis
text:
Alliance relevance and mechanisms — Through what mechanisms do offset or industrial participation policies affect alliance-relevant outcomes such as interoperability, standardisation, security of supply, readiness, and the ability to contribute rapidly to NATO operations?
This synthesis uses only the RQ1-coded CMO statements. The evidence base mixes high-confidence case studies/comparative case studies with a small number of more conceptual/theory-model claims; where outcomes are framed as “expected” or “aimed”, these are treated as conceptual rather than empirically observed. (calcara_20_pdf__cmo_002, weiss_19_pdf__cmo_003, kanniainen_17_pdf__cmo_002)



Interoperability and Standardisation (n≈9)
Readiness and Sustainment Support (n≈20–25)
Security of Supply and Autonomy (n≈10–15)
Defence-Industrial Capability and Technology Transfer (n≈20–30)
Programme Performance, Cost, and Governance (n≈10–15)
Alliance Political Leverage, Trust, and Network Position (n≈5–10)





Programmatic integration for common standards: In contexts where multilateral operations and interoperability priorities drive cooperation, pooling and standardising equipment is framed as a route to interoperability. Mechanism: cooperation provides economies of scale and standardisation, aligning equipment and practices across partners. Outcome: improved interoperability/standardisation (often stated as expected rather than directly measured). (weiss_19_pdf__cmo_002, calcara_20_pdf__cmo_002)
Offsets embedded in alliance-linked defence sales: In contexts of established security relationships and export-driven defence sales, offsets/industrial compensation are used as inducements. Mechanism: offering technology transfer/production arrangements within sales packages reinforces alliance ties and supports interoperability aims. Outcome: defence sales proceed with industrial compensation explicitly embedding alliance-building and interoperability goals. (16_offset_policies_and_trends_in_japan_south_korea_and_taiwan_pdf__cmo_001)
Interoperability-driven technology sharing under constraint: In contexts where interoperability requirements are tied to sensitive technologies, interoperability can require technology release. Mechanism: achieving interoperability necessitates sharing sensitive technology with partners (sometimes conditional on technology-access arrangements and approvals). Outcome: sensitive technology is shared with partners; governance around technology release becomes an active constraint on the pathway. (hagelin_12_pdf__cmo_002, 08_offsets_and_the_joint_strike_fighter_in_the_uk_and_the_netherlands_pdf__cmo_006)
Interoperability as a driver of costly acceleration dynamics: In contexts combining interoperability priorities with budget constraints and political pressure, technology sharing is framed as creating pressure to advance next-generation development. Mechanism: interoperability/technology sharing is used to justify accelerating “next generation” development to preserve an edge. Outcome: higher taxpayer costs and an arms-race dynamic among allies. (05_arms_trade_as_illiberal_trade_pdf__cmo_017)





Direct offsets building maintenance/modification competence: In contexts where imported systems generate sustainment dependence, direct military offsets can be targeted at maintenance and modification capacity. Mechanism: offsets provide resources/training/work packages that build local maintenance and modification capability, shifting actors toward in-country sustainment. Outcome: strengthened domestic sustainment competence supporting readiness. (10_evaluating_defense_offsets_the_experience_in_finland_and_sweden_pdf__cmo_017, 16_offset_policies_and_trends_in_japan_south_korea_and_taiwan_pdf__cmo_021)
Targeted MRO skill formation through selective cooperation: In contexts of small-state constraints and explicit prioritisation of sustainment skills, offsets/IP are used selectively for training and specialised repair/upgrade activities. Mechanism: collaboration and training requirements focus learning-by-doing on readiness-critical subsystems rather than broad industrialisation. Outcome: expanded MRO/upgrade capacity and improved overhaul capability for lifecycle support. (17_offsets_and_defense_industrialization_in_indonesia_and_singapore_pdf__cmo_013, 17_offsets_and_defense_industrialization_in_indonesia_and_singapore_pdf__cmo_014, 17_offsets_and_defense_industrialization_in_indonesia_and_singapore_pdf__cmo_015)
Re-focusing offsets towards defence-relevant sustainment outcomes: In contexts where policy shifts away from civil/economic offsets toward defence-technology competence (and/or where military requirements must dominate procurement), offset demands are redirected. Mechanism: restricting offsets’ role in supplier selection and prioritising defence-relevant technology/sustainment objectives reduces distortion and concentrates offset effort on lifecycle-support competencies. Outcome: offsets are redirected to defence-industrial participation and maintenance/technology competence and constrained to a secondary role in procurement evaluation. (10_evaluating_defense_offsets_the_experience_in_finland_and_sweden_pdf__cmo_016, 09_nordic_offset_policies_changes_and_challenges_pdf__cmo_004, 09_nordic_offset_policies_changes_and_challenges_pdf__cmo_008)
Boundary conditions from scale and duration of support: In contexts of very small fleets and limited support commitments, sustainment economics become fragile. Mechanism: small scale and short windows for spares/support weaken long-term supportability and deter external buyers. Outcome: high sustainment costs and reduced export viability (with sustainment activity potentially persisting only in narrow forms). (14_the_argentine_defense_industry_an_evaluation_pdf__cmo_010, 14_the_argentine_defense_industry_an_evaluation_pdf__cmo_007, 14_the_argentine_defense_industry_an_evaluation_pdf__cmo_005)





Security of supply via maintenance capacity (including theory-model claims): In contexts where importers face security risks and dependence, offsets are framed as improving security by sustaining maintenance capability and equipment availability. Mechanism: offsets function as an “insurance” logic and/or build maintenance capacity that reduces vulnerability to external suppliers. Outcome: improved security of supply / strengthened national security (noting this includes theory-model framing). Mechanism: creating domestic entities for software development/technology absorption and requiring transfer of sensitive artefacts increases control over operation, maintenance, and upgrades; suppliers’ willingness/ability to release technology becomes a binding constraint. Outcome: strengthened operational/maintenance autonomy, with bidder disadvantage where source-code transfer is non-negotiable. Mechanism: interoperability requirements constrain feasible sourcing and reinforce a path-dependent procurement trajectory. Outcome: reduced supplier diversity and greater reliance on JSF-style buy-multinational procurement models. (18_defense_offsets_in_australia_and_new_zealand_pdf__cmo_021)

(13_offsets_and_the_development_of_the_brazilian_arms_industry_pdf__cmo_003, 12_the_defense_industry_in_poland_an_offsets_based_revival_pdf__cmo_017, 15_the_role_of_offsets_in_indian_defense_procurement_policy_pdf__cmo_004)
Sustainment-focused designs more directly connect to readiness and security of supply: direct offsets and targeted cooperation aimed at maintenance/modification/MRO are repeatedly linked to readiness-relevant capabilities, whereas broad industrialisation goals are treated as diverging strategies. (10_evaluating_defense_offsets_the_experience_in_finland_and_sweden_pdf__cmo_017, 17_offsets_and_defense_industrialization_in_indonesia_and_singapore_pdf__cmo_002, 17_offsets_and_defense_industrialization_in_indonesia_and_singapore_pdf__cmo_013)
Governance choices can mitigate or amplify distortion: rules that keep offsets secondary to military requirements/value-for-money are explicitly framed as anti-distortion safeguards; conversely, complex collaborative governance and non-competitive work splitting are linked to higher costs/delays. (09_nordic_offset_policies_changes_and_challenges_pdf__cmo_008, 07_comparing_british_and_german_offset_strategies_pdf__cmo_003, 08_offsets_and_the_joint_strike_fighter_in_the_uk_and_the_netherlands_pdf__cmo_001)
Export-control/technology-release constraints are binding moderators: where autonomy or interoperability requires sensitive technology release (e.g., software source code), outcomes depend on supplier willingness/ability and approval processes, which can reshape competition and feasible partnering. (13_offsets_and_the_development_of_the_brazilian_arms_industry_pdf__cmo_020, hagelin_12_pdf__cmo_002, 08_offsets_and_the_joint_strike_fighter_in_the_uk_and_the_netherlands_pdf__cmo_006)
Scale and market viability constrain sustainment and export outcomes: small fleets and short support commitments are linked to high sustainment costs and weak export prospects, limiting any alliance-relevant benefits from domestic participation. (14_the_argentine_defense_industry_an_evaluation_pdf__cmo_010, 14_the_argentine_defense_industry_an_evaluation_pdf__cmo_007)

The CMOs also point to mixed/contested implications: interoperability can be supported by programme integration and standardisation, but is also framed as generating costly acceleration dynamics under budget and political pressures. (16_offset_policies_and_trends_in_japan_south_korea_and_taiwan_pdf__cmo_004, 05_arms_trade_as_illiberal_trade_pdf__cmo_017)




In contexts where imported systems create sustainment dependence, offsets/IP may support readiness and faster operational contribution by building in-country maintenance/modification competence via direct military offsets or sustainment-centred cooperation. (10_evaluating_defense_offsets_the_experience_in_finland_and_sweden_pdf__cmo_017, 17_offsets_and_defense_industrialization_in_indonesia_and_singapore_pdf__cmo_014)
In contexts where interoperability is prioritised, alliance outcomes may be supported through multinational programme structures (joint development/risk sharing) that integrate partners into common standards earlier, potentially reducing reliance on post-sale offsets. (16_offset_policies_and_trends_in_japan_south_korea_and_taiwan_pdf__cmo_004, weiss_19_pdf__cmo_002)
In contexts where domestic absorptive capacity is strong (R&D institutions, trained personnel), offsets/IP may support security-of-supply-relevant autonomy by enabling technology absorption and domestic control over sustainment and evolution (including software). (13_offsets_and_the_development_of_the_brazilian_arms_industry_pdf__cmo_003, 13_offsets_and_the_development_of_the_brazilian_arms_industry_pdf__cmo_017)
In contexts where technology release is constrained (export controls, source-code restrictions), offsets/IP may fail to deliver autonomy/interoperability pathways; procurement may need to treat technology-access feasibility as a binding condition rather than an assumed benefit. (13_offsets_and_the_development_of_the_brazilian_arms_industry_pdf__cmo_020, hagelin_12_pdf__cmo_002)
In contexts where collaborative programmes rely on non-competitive work splitting and complex governance, alliance capability goals may be undermined by cost/delay and fragmentation; constraining offsets’ role in supplier selection is one stated guardrail. (08_offsets_and_the_joint_strike_fighter_in_the_uk_and_the_netherlands_pdf__cmo_001, 09_nordic_offset_policies_changes_and_challenges_pdf__cmo_008)
In contexts where political assurance or leverage is a primary objective, offsets/IP may function as alliance-management tools by creating interdependence and network ties; strategy should treat this as a distinct mechanism from capability/readiness outcomes. (16_offset_policies_and_trends_in_japan_south_korea_and_taiwan_pdf__cmo_018, spindel_24_pdf__cmo_004)
Boundary condition / risk of overreach: where domestic production is small-scale/non-competitive or offsets are met via indirect/investment channels that dilute defence linkage, intended readiness/autonomy gains may not materialise and opportunity costs may be high. (14_the_argentine_defense_industry_an_evaluation_pdf__cmo_002, 19_defense_industrial_participation_the_south_african_experience_pdf__cmo_008, 20_defense_offsets_and_regional_development_in_south_africa_pdf__cmo_020)

title: What is a Prisma Diagram
text:
A PRISMA diagram is a flow diagram used in systematic reviews and meta-analyses to show how studies were identified, screened, and selected for inclusion.
It comes from the PRISMA Statement (Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Reviews and Meta-Analyses) and is mainly about transparency — letting readers see exactly what happened to all the studies you found.



Image


What the diagram shows (step by step)
Typically, a PRISMA diagram tracks studies through four stages:

Identification

Records found through database searches
Records found through other sources (e.g. references, grey literature)

Screening

Records after duplicates removed
Records screened by title and abstract
Records excluded at this stage

Eligibility

Full-text articles assessed
Full-text articles excluded (with reasons)

Included

Studies included in the qualitative synthesis
Studies included in the quantitative synthesis (meta-analysis), if applicable


Why it matters

Makes the review reproducible
Shows potential bias or subjectivity in study selection
Required or strongly encouraged by most academic journals
Helps readers quickly judge the rigour of the review

title: Outcome BERTopic Model (for Outcome Families)
text:
4 BERTopic (UMAP + HDBSCAN + Vectorization + c-TF-IDF)

import itertools
import numpy as np

from bertopic import BERTopic
from bertopic.representation import KeyBERTInspired, MaximalMarginalRelevance
from bertopic.vectorizers import ClassTfidfTransformer
from hdbscan import HDBSCAN
from sklearn.feature_extraction.text import CountVectorizer
from sentence_transformers import SentenceTransformer
from umap import UMAP

vectorizer_model = CountVectorizer(
    stop_words="english",
    ngram_range=(1, 3),
    min_df=2,
)

ctfidf_model = ClassTfidfTransformer(
    reduce_frequent_words=True,
)

base_representation_model = {
    "KeyBERT": KeyBERTInspired(top_n_words=12),
    "MMR": MaximalMarginalRelevance(diversity=0.5),
}

embedding_backend = SentenceTransformer(model_name, device=device)

random_state = 42

target_topics_min = 8
target_topics_max = 40
max_outlier_rate_soft = 0.50

tuning_sample_size = 2000

min_cluster_sizes = [5, 8, 10, 15, 20]
min_samples_list = [1, 2, 5]
umap_n_neighbors_list = [5, 10, 15]
cluster_selection_methods = ["eom", "leaf"]
umap_n_components = 5
umap_min_dist = 0.0

use_openai_topic_labels = True
openai_model = "gpt-4o-mini"
openai_delay_seconds = 1

openai_representation_model = None
if use_openai_topic_labels:
    try:
        import openai
        from dotenv import load_dotenv
        from bertopic.representation import OpenAI as OpenAIRepresentation

        load_dotenv()
        openai_api_key = os.getenv("OPENAI_API_KEY")
        if openai_api_key:
            openai_client = openai.OpenAI(api_key=openai_api_key)
            openai_representation_model = OpenAIRepresentation(
                openai_client,
                model=openai_model,
                delay_in_seconds=openai_delay_seconds,
            )
            print("OpenAI topic labelling enabled (OPENAI_API_KEY found in environment).")
        else:
            print("OpenAI topic labelling disabled (OPENAI_API_KEY not found).")
    except Exception as e:
        openai_representation_model = None
        print("OpenAI topic labelling disabled (optional):", type(e).__name__, str(e)[:200])


def _score(outlier_rate: float, n_topics: int) -> float:
    topic_penalty = 0.0
    if n_topics < target_topics_min:
        topic_penalty += (target_topics_min - n_topics) / max(target_topics_min, 1)
    if n_topics > target_topics_max:
        topic_penalty += (n_topics - target_topics_max) / max(target_topics_max, 1)

    outlier_penalty = 0.0
    if outlier_rate > max_outlier_rate_soft:
        outlier_penalty = (outlier_rate - max_outlier_rate_soft) * 2.0

    return float(outlier_rate + 0.35 * topic_penalty + outlier_penalty)


def fit_topic_model(
    min_cluster_size: int, min_samples: int, umap_n_neighbors: int, cluster_selection_method: str
):
    umap_model = UMAP(
        n_neighbors=umap_n_neighbors,
        n_components=umap_n_components,
        min_dist=umap_min_dist,
        metric="cosine",
        random_state=random_state,
    )

    hdbscan_model = HDBSCAN(
        min_cluster_size=min_cluster_size,
        min_samples=min_samples,
        metric="euclidean",
        cluster_selection_method=cluster_selection_method,
        prediction_data=True,
    )

    topic_model = BERTopic(
        embedding_model=embedding_backend,
        vectorizer_model=vectorizer_model,
        ctfidf_model=ctfidf_model,
        representation_model=base_representation_model,
        umap_model=umap_model,
        hdbscan_model=hdbscan_model,
        top_n_words=12,
        calculate_probabilities=False,
        verbose=False,
    )

    topics, _ = topic_model.fit_transform(tune_docs, tune_embeddings)
    topic_info = topic_model.get_topic_info()
    n_non_outlier_topics = int((topic_info["Topic"] != -1).sum())
    outlier_rate = float(np.mean(np.asarray(topics) == -1))
    return topic_model, topics, topic_info, n_non_outlier_topics, outlier_rate


if len(docs) > tuning_sample_size:
    rng = np.random.default_rng(random_state)
    tune_idx = rng.choice(len(docs), size=tuning_sample_size, replace=False)
    tune_docs = [docs[i] for i in tune_idx]
    tune_embeddings = embeddings[tune_idx]
    print(f"Tuning on a random sample of {len(tune_docs)} / {len(docs)} outcome statements")
else:
    tune_docs = docs
    tune_embeddings = embeddings
    print(f"Tuning on full dataset with {len(docs)} outcome statements")

results = []
best = None

for min_cluster_size, min_samples, umap_n_neighbors in itertools.product(
    min_cluster_sizes, min_samples_list, umap_n_neighbors_list
):
    for cluster_selection_method in cluster_selection_methods:
        model, tpcs, info, n_t, out_rate = fit_topic_model(
            min_cluster_size=min_cluster_size,
            min_samples=min_samples,
            umap_n_neighbors=umap_n_neighbors,
            cluster_selection_method=cluster_selection_method,
        )

        score = _score(out_rate, n_t)
        row = {
            "min_cluster_size": min_cluster_size,
            "min_samples": min_samples,
            "umap_n_neighbors": umap_n_neighbors,
            "cluster_selection_method": cluster_selection_method,
            "n_topics": n_t,
            "outlier_rate": out_rate,
            "score": score,
        }
        results.append(row)

        if best is None or score < best["row"]["score"]:
            best = {"row": row, "model": model, "topics": tpcs, "topic_info": info}

tuning_df = pd.DataFrame(results).sort_values(["score", "outlier_rate", "n_topics"]).reset_index(drop=True)
tuning_df.to_csv(os.path.join(out_dir, "tuning_results.csv"), index=False)
print("Saved tuning table to", os.path.join(out_dir, "tuning_results.csv"))
tuning_df.head(15)

best_params = {
    k: best["row"][k]
    for k in ["min_cluster_size", "min_samples", "umap_n_neighbors", "cluster_selection_method"]
}
print("Best params from tuning:", best_params)
import json

with open(os.path.join(out_dir, "best_params.json"), "w", encoding="utf-8") as f:
    json.dump(
        {
            "best_params": best_params,
            "targets": {
                "target_topics_min": target_topics_min,
                "target_topics_max": target_topics_max,
                "max_outlier_rate_soft": max_outlier_rate_soft,
            },
            "grid": {
                "min_cluster_sizes": min_cluster_sizes,
                "min_samples_list": min_samples_list,
                "umap_n_neighbors_list": umap_n_neighbors_list,
                "cluster_selection_methods": cluster_selection_methods,
                "umap_n_components": umap_n_components,
                "umap_min_dist": umap_min_dist,
                "tuning_sample_size": tuning_sample_size,
            },
        },
        f,
        indent=2,
        sort_keys=True,
    )

# Refit final model on the full dataset with the selected parameters
def fit_final_topic_model(params: dict):
    umap_model = UMAP(
        n_neighbors=int(params["umap_n_neighbors"]),
        n_components=umap_n_components,
        min_dist=umap_min_dist,
        metric="cosine",
        random_state=random_state,
    )
    hdbscan_model = HDBSCAN(
        min_cluster_size=int(params["min_cluster_size"]),
        min_samples=int(params["min_samples"]),
        metric="euclidean",
        cluster_selection_method=str(params["cluster_selection_method"]),
        prediction_data=True,
    )
    def _fit(rep_model: dict, verbose: bool):
        topic_model = BERTopic(
            embedding_model=embedding_backend,
            vectorizer_model=vectorizer_model,
            ctfidf_model=ctfidf_model,
            representation_model=rep_model,
            umap_model=umap_model,
            hdbscan_model=hdbscan_model,
            top_n_words=12,
            calculate_probabilities=False,
            verbose=verbose,
        )
        topics, _ = topic_model.fit_transform(docs, embeddings)
        topic_info = topic_model.get_topic_info()
        n_non_outlier_topics = int((topic_info["Topic"] != -1).sum())
        outlier_rate = float(np.mean(np.asarray(topics) == -1))
        return topic_model, topics, topic_info, n_non_outlier_topics, outlier_rate

    rep_model = dict(base_representation_model)
    if openai_representation_model is not None:
        rep_model["OpenAI"] = openai_representation_model
        try:
            return _fit(rep_model, verbose=True)
        except Exception as e:
            print("OpenAI representation failed; refitting without OpenAI:", type(e).__name__, str(e)[:200])

    return _fit(dict(base_representation_model), verbose=True)


topic_model, topics, topic_info, n_topics, outlier_rate = fit_final_topic_model(best_params)
print("Final model | n_topics:", n_topics, "| outlier_rate:", round(outlier_rate, 3))


def _coerce_label(value) -> str | None:
    if value is None:
        return None
    if isinstance(value, str):
        return value.strip() or None
    if isinstance(value, (list, tuple)) and len(value) > 0:
        first = value[0]
        if isinstance(first, tuple) and len(first) > 0:
            parts = []
            for item in value[:4]:
                if isinstance(item, tuple) and len(item) > 0:
                    parts.append(str(item[0]))
            label = ", ".join([p for p in parts if p])
            return label or None
        if isinstance(first, str):
            label = ", ".join([str(x) for x in value[:4] if str(x).strip()])
            return label or None
    return None


topic_labels = {}
if openai_representation_model is not None and hasattr(topic_model, "topic_aspects_"):
    aspects = getattr(topic_model, "topic_aspects_", {}) or {}
    openai_aspects = aspects.get("OpenAI")
    if isinstance(openai_aspects, dict):
        for tid in topic_info["Topic"].tolist():
            if tid == -1:
                continue
            topic_labels[int(tid)] = _coerce_label(openai_aspects.get(int(tid)))

# Fallback labels from default c-TF-IDF top words
for tid in topic_info["Topic"].tolist():
    if tid == -1:
        continue
    if topic_labels.get(int(tid)):
        continue
    words = topic_model.get_topic(int(tid)) or []
    top_words = [w for w, _ in words[:3]]
    topic_labels[int(tid)] = ", ".join(top_words) if top_words else f"Topic {tid}"

if hasattr(topic_model, "set_topic_labels") and topic_labels:
    topic_model.set_topic_labels(topic_labels)

labels_csv = os.path.join(out_dir, "topic_labels.csv")
labels_df = pd.DataFrame(
    [{"topic": int(t), "label": str(l)} for t, l in sorted(topic_labels.items(), key=lambda x: x[0])]
)
labels_df.to_csv(labels_csv, index=False)
print(f"Wrote {labels_csv} with {len(labels_df)} topic labels")

import os
import openai
from dotenv import load_dotenv
from bertopic import BERTopic
from bertopic.representation import KeyBERTInspired, MaximalMarginalRelevance
from bertopic.representation import OpenAI as OpenAIRepresentation
from sklearn.feature_extraction.text import CountVectorizer
from sentence_transformers import SentenceTransformer
from hdbscan import HDBSCAN
from umap import UMAP

load_dotenv()

docs = df["mechanism_statement"].tolist()

vectorizer_model = CountVectorizer(
    stop_words="english",
    ngram_range=(1, 3),
    min_df=2,
)

representation_model = {
    "KeyBERT": KeyBERTInspired(top_n_words=12),
    "MMR": MaximalMarginalRelevance(diversity=0.5),
}

openai_api_key = os.getenv("OPENAI_API_KEY")
if openai_api_key:
    openai_client = openai.OpenAI(api_key=openai_api_key)
    representation_model["OpenAI"] = OpenAIRepresentation(
        openai_client,
        model="gpt-4o-mini",
        delay_in_seconds=1,
    )

umap_model = UMAP(
    n_neighbors=10,
    n_components=5,
    min_dist=0.0,
    metric="cosine",
    random_state=42,
)

hdbscan_model = HDBSCAN(
    min_cluster_size=8,
    min_samples=4,
    metric="euclidean",
    cluster_selection_method="eom",
    prediction_data=True,
)

embedding_backend = SentenceTransformer(model_name, device="cpu")

topic_model = BERTopic(
    embedding_model=embedding_backend,
    vectorizer_model=vectorizer_model,
    top_n_words=12,
    representation_model=representation_model,
    umap_model=umap_model,
    hdbscan_model=hdbscan_model,
    calculate_probabilities=False,
    verbose=True,
)

topics, _ = topic_model.fit_transform(docs, embeddings)

reducer = UMAP(
    n_neighbors=10,
    n_components=2,
    min_dist=0.0,
    metric="cosine",
    random_state=42,
)
reduced_embeddings = reducer.fit_transform(embeddings)

fig = topic_model.visualize_document_datamap(
    docs,
    reduced_embeddings=reduced_embeddings,
    interactive=True,
)
fig

title: 1 OFFSETS Literature Review
text:
A realist evidence synthesis and comparative case mapping of defence offsets/industrial participation policies, with a focus on alliance-relevant outcomes (e.g., interoperability, readiness, security of supply) and the conditions under which offsets help or hinder strategic partnerships.



Explain how offset and industrial participation policies interact with NATO-aligned defence priorities.
Identify mechanisms and conditions that lead to durable industrial collaboration with allies and partners.
Surface recurring risks (e.g., cost inflation, governance/opacity, corruption, export-control friction) and mitigation approaches.
Map comparative country cases that demonstrate positive, negative, or mixed outcomes under different offset regimes.





Under what contexts do offsets/industrial participation mechanisms enable alliance-relevant outcomes (interoperability, readiness, security of supply, partnership durability)?
Which mechanisms systematically hinder those outcomes, and through what governance or market conditions?
How do policy design choices (mandatory vs. voluntary, direct vs. indirect, transparency/enforcement) shape collaboration depth and risk profiles across cases?
How can each pathway be summarized with enabling/limiting conditions and alliance-relevant outcomes?
What recurrent pathways can be mapped across countries to explain positive, negative, or mixed outcomes?





Realist evidence synthesis (CMO): Extracts Context-Mechanism-Outcome configurations from sources, then clusters mechanism tags into a small set of pathways (themes) to explain what works, for whom, and under what conditions; thematic summaries link pathways to alliance-relevant outcomes and enabling or constraining contexts.
Comparative case mapping: Uses a consistent rubric to compare countries and programmes on policy design, depth of collaboration, alliance integration markers, and documented risks.
Two-lane search strategy: Parallel searches for (1) offsets/industrial participation literature and (2) alliance-relevant industrial cooperation/interoperability literature to avoid terminology gaps.
Evidence mix: Academic literature plus targeted grey literature (government policy, audits, NATO/EU material, and governance analyses).

In practice, the realist synthesis proceeds by extracting discrete CMO statements from each source, tagging contexts, mechanisms, and outcomes, and then grouping mechanisms into a small number of thematic pathways. Those pathways are summarized against alliance-relevant outcomes (interoperability, readiness, security of supply, partnership durability) and the contextual conditions that enable or constrain them. The mechanism map provides a traceable bridge from individual CMO records to thematic findings.
An iterative realist synthesis process combining inductive mechanism discovery, constant-comparative theme refinement, and theory consolidation prior to context–mechanism–outcome pattern building/
If you have, say, 180 mechanisms:
Start with 25 → generate initial themes
Next 25 → iterative classification
Repeat
Every ~75 mechanisms → run a merge/split audit
SOURCE DOCUMENTS
       │
       ▼
Stage 0 — Extract Mechanism Statements (AI Assist)
       │
       │  • Identify “how/why” causal explanations
       │  • Write short mechanism statements
       │  • Assign stable IDs (MECH_001, MECH_002…)
       ▼
Mechanism Bank (raw data)
       │
       ▼
Stage 1 — Initial Theme Discovery (AI-assisted)
       │
       │  Input: First batch (≈20–30 mechanisms)
       │  Task: Group by shared generative process
       │  Output: Proto-mechanism themes (PM1, PM2…)
       ▼
Initial Mechanism Framework
       │
       ▼
Stage 2 — Iterative Constant Comparison (AI-assisted, repeated)
       │
       │  For each new batch (≈15–25 mechanisms):
       │   • Compare to existing themes
       │   • Assign to existing theme OR
       │   • Create new theme OR
       │   • Mark ambiguous
       ▼
Expanded Mechanism Framework
       │
       ▼
Stage 3 — Theme Quality Control (AI-assisted audit)
       │
       │  • Merge themes that describe same process
       │  • Split themes containing multiple mechanisms
       │  • Remove vague or non-mechanism themes
       ▼
Refined Mechanism Framework
       │
       ▼
Stage 4 — Mechanism Saturation Check (Human judgement)
       │
       │  Ask:
       │  • Do new mechanisms mostly fit existing themes?
       │  • Are new themes rare and substantively distinct?
       ▼
Stabilised Set of Mechanism Themes
       │
       ▼
Stage 5 — Link Mechanisms to Contexts (Next synthesis phase)
       │
       │  Identify patterns:
       │  “In context X, mechanism Y tends to fire”
       ▼
Stage 6 — Link Mechanisms to Outcomes
       │
       │  Identify outcome tendencies:
       │  “When Y fires, outcome Z is more/less likely”
       ▼
Stage 7 — Build CMO Demi-Regularities
       │
       │  Context + Mechanism → Outcome patterns
       ▼
Stage 8 — Develop Explanatory Propositions
       │
       │  Middle-range theory statements, e.g.:
       │  “Where domestic absorptive capacity is high,
       │   learning-by-doing mechanisms generate
       │   sustained industrial capability.”
       ▼
Final Realist Synthesis
